docs.title: Welcome
docs.text: A guide on how to save time in capturing timesheets with the assistance of Time Tracker

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Consider these questions:

  • Did I start my day at 7:30 AM or 7:45 AM?
  • Did I spend 15 minutes or 45 minutes looking at a support ticket?
  • How long was I out for my lunch break?
  • Am I working too many hours or too few hours?
  • When I forget to complete my timesheet every day, how do I figure out what I did?

If you answered yes to any of the above questions, and you work on a computer most of the day, then Time Tracker is the answer all of the above questions.

docs.title: Installing Time Tracker
docs.text:
There currently isn't an installer for the tool. Take the TimeTracker.Windows.1.4.2.zip and extract it anywhere on your computer.

Start the application by running the TimeTrackerService.bat file.

Warning

You cannot run this application without extracting it from the .zip file

By default, the application isn't set to auto start. You can turn on this functionality in Global Settings (the Auto Start Application option) to add Time Tracker to your startup applications.

When the application is running you'll see it's icon in the system tray

To use the application either:

  • Left-click on the tray icon
  • Right-click on the tray icon and select Capture Time
  • Open your browser and navigate to http://localhost:8093

To get started with using the tool have a look at the Capture Screen

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Auto Capture allows the tool to automatically capture the time if the window name or application name matches the provided filters.

The window name and application name are case-insensitive and check if the filter contains the provided text. For example, if I filter "Outlook" for the window name window name, it would match "Microsoft Outlook", "Mail - Outlook", etc.

Then you can select which client, project, activity, ticket number, description where this time will be auto-captured

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Time Tracker tracks the duration of the currently focused window title and application path. Every time you focus on a new window, Time Tracker takes a screenshot and captures the new window title and application path.

After using the tool for a few hours, it's easy to find out what you've been doing all day.

To track time, hover over the Start area until you find the time you want to track and click the item you want to track. Next, hover over the time in the End capture area and click the end of the activity for which you want to capture time.

Tip

Use the screenshots to see what you have done.

Now that you have selected the start and end time for the activity, either click the Allocate Time button or select any area in the Capture line.

Fill in what you did during this period. In my case, I worked on the documentation for this tool.

When you are finished, click the Save button.

Now that you have allocated your time, it will appear in blue on the capture line.

Tip

You can record additional time to any time you have previously recorded by simply selecting a new Start and End time and then selecting the blue capture line. of an existing client/project/activity.

Tip

You can search for any part of the application path, window title, client name, project name or activity name using the global search box in the top right-hand corner.

When you are done for the day you can easily see what activities you have spent your day on by simply clicking on the Summary button.

You can adjust the application settings by selecting the Administration >> Global Settings button.

Sometimes you may have some items you want to captur, such as a password spreadsheet, or a sensitive email. To exclude screenshots for specific applications or windows simply add an exclusion by clicking on the Administration >> Exclusions button.

Do you have daily repetitive tasks such as answering emails, checking on ticket statuses etc? To simplify this process you can set up automatic tagging by using the Administration >> Auto Capture button.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Exclusions allow the tool to exclude certain applications or window titles from being logged or prevent screenshots from being taken.

Exclusions are case-insensitive and check if the filter contains the provided text. E.g. if I select the filter "team" for Window Name, this would match, "Microsoft Teams", "Team Foundation Server", "Team Fortress".

I can then choose to hide the screenshot, the window name and/or the application name.

docs.title: Where is Time Tracker's data stored on my machine?
docs.text:
Navigate to C:\Users\fill-in-your-user-name-here\AppData\Local\TimeTracker in File Explorer

  • logs - the application error logs used for diagnosing issues
  • Screenshots - folder has the screenshots taken by the application divided by day.
  • time-tracker.db - the SQLLite database storing all previously tracked time

Tip

Clean out old screenshots from time to time as this folder can grow quite large

docs.title: How to I backup Time Tracker's data as I'm changing to a new PC
docs.text:
See the section where Time Tracker is storing its data. Copy or zip the contents of the folder to your backup medium.

Then simply create the TimeTracker folder in the **\AppData\Local** folder on your new computer and start Time Tracker

docs.title: I would like to Sync my Time Tracker data between multiple machines. How would I go about that?
docs.text: Unfortunately Time Tracker does not have any networking capabilities at present. If this is a very common requirement then I will consider building in this functionality in future

docs.title: How to remove Time Tracker from my computer?
docs.text:
Find the Time Tracker tray icon

Right-click on the tray icon and select the Exit menu option

Next, we will remove the screenshots and database for the tool. In File Explorer, navigate to C: \Users\fill-in-your-user-name-here\AppData\Local\TimeTracker now delete the contents of this folder

Finally, remove the zip file and the files you have extracted.

Time Tracker will now be completely uninstalled from your computer.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
Click on the Global Settings button to change the global settings for the tool.

  • Screen Poll Interval (In Minutes) - the time between polling for screen changes. e.g. if I selected 3 minutes then the tool would only check for active window changes every 3 minutes.
  • Idle Time Threshold (In Minutes) - the number of minutes before marking time as idle
  • No Activity Threshold (In Minutes) - the number of minutes before detecting that the computer/laptop was off
  • Auto Start Application - Launch tool automatically when your user logs in
  • Round Up Minutes - Add this number of minutes to to the base number of minutes (default 10). This prevents 5 minute tasks from being lost
  • Round By Minutes - Divide the rounded up minutes by this value (default 15) to ensure more consisted time captured

Remember to select the Save button for your changes to take effect.

Warning

If you enable "Auto Start Application" but you disable the application in the Startup Apps in Windows Settings then Time Tracker will obey the windows settings and not start up.

Note

The formula for Rounded time is rounded = (original_Time + round_up_minutes) / round_by_minutes * round_by_minutes. Be default this will make 5 minutes 15 minutes and 51 minutes will round to 1 hour. They allow for more precise control over time tracking and can help to ensure consistency in reported times.

docs.title: Introduction
docs.text:
The Summary screen shows you all the activities you achieved for your day rounded off to the nearest 15 minutes. If you repeated the same activity again later in the day, the time is combined as one.

Using the summary screen, you can very easily see how much time you spent on completing your tasks for completing your daily timesheets.

docs.title: Monthly Summary
docs.text:
If you would like to see which projects you worked on for the entire month. Simply select the Month Summary button.

You can adjust the start and end day for the "Month Summary" by changing the Start and End dates. So you can easily see what you did for the last week, month, year, etc.
